intro: Cinchona succirubra var. vera, commonly known as the Peruvian bark or quina, is a species native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its evergreen tree or shrub form. The plant is notable for its dark red to orange-red bark, which contains high concentrations of quinine, a compound historically used to treat malaria. Its leaves are typically elliptical with a pointed tip and are arranged alternately along the stems. This variety is often cultivated for its medicinal properties and is an important species in the production of antimalarial drugs.
